curriculumTitle: Powering the Future: Micro-Grids and Renewable Energy Systems (Modular)
overview: This comprehensive hands-on curriculum utilizes a 300W/260Wh portable solar generator to teach high school students the principles of photovoltaic energy conversion, battery storage technology, electrical load calculation, and sustainable engineering design. Adjusted for standard scheduling, this curriculum is divided into eight 40-minute sessions suitable for daily classroom instruction or segmented Saturday Academy workshops. It is designed to meet strict DOE TRIO compliance for instruction in Mathematics and Laboratory Science.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I (TEKS 111.39); Familiarity with basic Physical Science concepts (TEKS 112.39).

fieldTrips.name: Tarrant County College - South Campus (Renewable Energy Technology Center)
fieldTrips.description: A guided tour of the TCC Renewable Energy Technology program facilities, including their solar arrays and wind turbine simulators.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Directly correlates with the solar physics and career pathways discussed in Sessions 1 and 8. Demonstrates post-secondary technical degree options (AAS).

fieldTrips.name: Perot Museum of Nature and Science - Tom Hunt Energy Hall
fieldTrips.description: Interactive exploration of the Energy Hall, focusing on the transition from traditional hydrocarbons to renewable energy grids.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Reinforces the 'Blackout Scenario' (Sessions 6-7) by visualizing energy grid infrastructure and resource management.

activities.title: Session 1: The Physics of Photovoltaics
activities.description: Introduction to solar energy physics, electron flow, and safety protocols for handling DC current systems.
learningObjectives: Explain the photovoltaic effect and how solar panels convert irradiance into DC current.
Identify safety protocols for handling DC electrical equipment.
Differentiate between potential energy (Voltage) and current (Amperage).
teks: Physics 112.39(c)(5)(B): Demonstrate that moving electric charges produce magnetic fields.
Physics 112.39(c)(6)(D): Investigate movement of thermal energy by radiation.
texasStemStandards: Science Practices: Planning and carrying out investigations.
STEM Career Awareness: Introduction to Electrical Engineering.

materialsList.item: Portable Power Station (260Wh) with 40W Solar Panel

detailed: Introduce the unit and the portable power station equipment, ensuring all safety warnings are read.
Lecture on the Photovoltaic Effect: How photons knock electrons loose from silicon atoms to create current.
Brief students on safety regarding DC current (low voltage but high safety standards required, avoid moisture).
Demonstrate the basic connection of the panel to the generator unit using the Anderson Power Pole or MC4 connectors.
Examine the solar panel construction (silicon wafer design) without touching the glass directly.
Practice connecting and disconnecting the MC4 or Anderson connectors safely under supervision.
Hypothesize how sunlight intensity affects electron flow and write down predictions.

allowableServices: Exposure to Engineering and Technology Careers
trioCompliance.justification: Provides foundational science instruction required for laboratory activities. Equipment is <$5,000 unit cost, classified as supplies.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b)(1) (UBMS): Instruction in physical sciences.

stemConnections.science: Atomic structure, photons, and electron movement.
crossCurricularLinks: History: The discovery of the photoelectric effect (Einstein).

activities.title: Session 2: Solar Lab - Angle and Efficiency
activities.description: Field experiment measuring input variance based on angle of incidence and partial shading.
learningObjectives: Calculate the efficiency loss caused by sub-optimal angles of incidence.
Analyze the impact of partial shading on series vs. parallel solar cells.
Record and graph data regarding wattage input.
teks: Environmental Systems 112.37(c)(6)(D): Analyze impact of renewable energy.
Physics 112.39(c)(2)(H): Analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations.
texasStemStandards: Science Practices: Collecting and analyzing data.
Engineering Practices: Using mathematics and computational thinking.

detailed: Move class outdoors or to a direct sunlight window.
Assign roles per group: Panel Holder, Protractor Reader, Data Recorder.
Guide students to tilt panels at 0, 30, 45, and 90 degrees relative to the sun.
Facilitate discussion on why 40W panels rarely hit 40W (heat loss, atmospheric interference, conversion efficiency).
Connect the solar panel and aim directly at the sun to establish 'Max Baseline' wattage.
Adjust angles in 15-degree increments and log the wattage for each angle.
Cover 25% of the panel with cardboard and record the immediate drop in efficiency (simulating clouds/leaves).
Calculate the percentage difference between the rated 40W and actual max achieved.

trioCompliance.justification: Direct laboratory science activity involving data collection and analysis.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR § 645.11(b)(2): Personal counseling (mentoring during group work).

crossCurricularLinks: Geography: Latitude/Longitude effects on solar angles.

activities.title: Session 3: The Energy Bank - AC/DC & Inverters
activities.description: Exploration of battery storage technology, the difference between AC and DC power, and inverter mechanics.
learningObjectives: Differentiate between Direct Current (DC) and Alternating Current (AC).
Understand the function and efficiency loss of an inverter.
Define 'Watt-hour' as a unit of capacity.
teks: Physics 112.39(c)(6)(F): Design, construct, and calculate power used by electric circuit elements.
texasStemStandards: Science Practices: Developing and using models.

detailed: Explain that batteries store DC, but wall outlets provide AC (Tesla vs Edison concept).
Draw a diagram of an inverter converting DC to AC and explain the 'Heat Tax' (efficiency loss ~15% due to heat dissipation).
Define Wh (Watt-hours) as the 'size of the gas tank' and Watts (W) as 'how fast you drive'.
Identify the DC ports (USB, 12V) vs AC ports (Wall outlet) on the generator.
Hypothesize which port is more efficient for charging a phone and why (DC to DC vs DC to AC to DC).
Calculate the usable capacity of a 260Wh battery if the inverter is 85% efficient (260 * 0.85).

trioCompliance.justification: Deep dive into electrical theory and thermodynamics (inverter heat loss) suitable for UBMS rigor.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b)(1) (UBMS): Instruction in mathematics and science.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR § 200.407: Prior written approval (if curriculum development costs are claimed).

activities.title: Session 4: Load Analysis Lab
activities.description: Students measure actual power consumption of various devices to understand Surge vs. Continuous watts.
learningObjectives: Measure actual wattage draw of appliances.
Distinguish between Peak Surge and Continuous running watts.
Identify 'Vampire Loads' (power drawn when devices are off).
teks: Physics 112.39(c)(6)(F): Power used by electric circuit elements.

detailed: Demonstrate how to read the 'Output Watts' on the generator display.
Discuss the 300W Peak limit. Explain what happens if we plug in a hair dryer (1500W). Demonstrate overload protection safely.
Guide students to measure devices one by one and record values.
Create a data table for: Device Name, Rated Watts (sticker), Actual Watts (measured).
Plug in a laptop; observe the wattage when idle vs. when opening a large application (CPU surge).
Plug in a fan; observe wattage at Low, Medium, and High settings.

trioCompliance.justification: Hands-on measurement and data recording activity.

activities.title: Session 5: The Math of Battery Life
activities.description: A math-focused session calculating runtime formulas and predictions based on data collected in Session 4.
learningObjectives: Apply dimensional analysis to solve for Time (T).
Calculate runtime using the formula: T = (Capacity Wh * Efficiency) / Load W.
Compare theoretical calculations with real-world observed 'Time to Empty' values.
teks: Math Models 111.43(c)(3): Use problem-solving, mathematical language, and real-world situations to analyze models.

detailed: Present the Runtime Formula on the board: Time = (Battery Wh x 0.85) / Load Watts.
Walk through a sample problem: 260Wh battery, 85% efficiency, 60W lightbulb.
Assign a problem set based on the devices measured in the previous session.
Calculate how long the generator will last powering the fan on High (using your measured watts from Session 4).
Calculate how many times the generator can recharge a phone (Assume Phone battery = 12Wh).
Compare your math to the 'Time to Empty' number displayed on the generator screen during the lab.

trioCompliance.justification: Focuses explicitly on the 'Instruction in Mathematics' service required by TRIO, applying algebra to real-world physics.

activities.title: Session 6: The Blackout Scenario - Budgeting
activities.description: Introduction to the Engineering Challenge. Students receive emergency profiles and begin the energy budgeting process.
learningObjectives: Prioritize critical vs. non-critical electrical loads.
Design a power budget plan based on strict resource constraints.
teks: Engineering Design 130.365(c)(5): Solve problems using the engineering design process.
Environmental Systems 112.37(c)(5)(B): Evaluate costs and benefits of resource use.
texasStemStandards: Engineering Practices: Defining problems and constraints.

materialsList.item: Scenario Cards (e.g., Medical Needs, Comm Needs)

detailed: Divide students into teams of 3-4.
Hand out 'Emergency Profiles' (Scenario A: Nebulizer needed for asthma; Scenario B: Radio comms needed for rescue).
Set the Constraint: 1 full charge (260Wh) + limited solar refill opportunities.
Instruct students to list every device they *want* vs. *need* to survive.
Analyze your assigned scenario and identify the 'Must-Haves'.
Create a 'Load List' of all required devices and their wattage.
Determine which devices are life-safety critical and which are luxury.
Begin calculating the total Watt-hours required for a 24-hour period if everything ran constantly (to prove it's impossible).

trioCompliance.justification: Problem-based learning simulating real-world engineering constraints.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) (UB): Academic advice and assistance in course selection (via engineering problem solving).

crossCurricularLinks: Civics: Disaster response and community resilience.

activities.title: Session 7: The Blackout Scenario - Scheduling Simulation
activities.description: Students create a 24-hour timeline integrating solar recharge rates to ensure the battery never hits 0%.
learningObjectives: Create a time-domain simulation of energy usage.
Calculate solar recharge rates (Wh input) based on a 4-hour sun window.
Optimize a system to prevent failure (0% battery).

detailed: Provide the Solar Constraint: Assume 4 hours of sun (10am-2pm) at 30W average input (Total +120Wh).
Challenge: The battery must last 24 hours. It cannot drop below 0%.
Guide students to create a timeline (00:00 to 23:59) mapping Wh usage vs Time.
Draw a graph with Time (X-axis) and Battery % (Y-axis). Start at 100%.
Plot the energy drain as devices are used throughout the day.
Plot the energy gain during the solar window (add energy during 10 AM - 2 PM).
Adjust the usage schedule (turn off devices) if the line hits zero.

trioCompliance.justification: Advanced modeling and simulation activity aligning with UBMS goals for rigorous STEM curriculum.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b)(1) (UBMS): Mathematics and science instruction.

activities.title: Session 8: Grid Defense & Career Pathways
activities.description: Teams present their defense of their micro-grid strategy, followed by a discussion on careers in Renewable Energy.
learningObjectives: Present a technical justification for an energy management plan.
Identify careers in the renewable energy sector (Solar Technician, Grid Engineer).
Reflect on the importance of resilient infrastructure.
teks: Career Development 127.14(c)(1): Investigate one or more careers within the STEM endorsement.

detailed: Facilitate 5-minute presentations from each group.
Critique plans based on feasibility (e.g., 'Did you account for clouds during the solar window?').
Present career pathways: Solar Installer (Trade), Electrical Engineer (Degree), Grid Operator (Tech).
Discuss college majors that lead to these fields and local Texas universities with strong programs.
Present your 24-hour energy graph to the class.
Explain the hardest choice you had to make (e.g., turning off the fridge to charge the radio).
Participate in the Q&A regarding renewable energy careers and required degrees.

trioCompliance.justification: Satisfies 'Career Exploration' requirement for both UB and UBMS.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(4) (UB): Guidance on secondary school reentry or alternative education programs (Career Guidance).
edgarCitations: 2 CFR § 200.459: Professional service costs (if guest speaker is hired).
